title: Add element grouping functionality
description:
Allow grouping multiple elements to move/transform as a unit.

## Behavior

- Grouped elements move together
- Grouped elements resize together (proportionally)
- Can still select individual elements within group (Cmd/Ctrl+click)
- Ungroup command (Cmd/Ctrl+Shift+G)

## Implementation
- Create 'group' element type that contains child element references
- Store group ID on child elements
- Group has its own bounding box calculated from children
- Dragging group moves all children
- Resizing group scales all children proportionally

{
  'id': 'group-xxx',
  'type': 'group',
  'children': ['element-1', 'element-2'],
  'x': calculated,
  'y': calculated,
  'width': calculated,
  'height': calculated
}

## Requirements

- Keyboard shortcuts: Cmd/Ctrl+G to group, Cmd/Ctrl+Shift+G to ungroup
- Groups can be nested
- Integrate with undo/redo system
- Persists through save/load

title: Add OPML export/import for canvas hierarchy
description:
Implement OPML (Outline Processor Markup Language) export and import for the canvas hierarchy.

## Why OPML
- Standard XML-based outlining format
- Handles hierarchical data (canvas tree with folders) naturally
- Robust against special characters in labels (proper XML escaping)
- Widely supported by outline tools, can interop with other apps

## Export
- Export entire canvas tree to .opml file
- Each canvas becomes an outline node
- Folder elements create child nodes linking to their target canvases
- Include element metadata as OPML attributes or nested nodes
- Handle images: either embed as base64 or reference external paths

## Import
- Load .opml file and reconstruct canvas hierarchy
- Create canvases for each outline node
- Recreate folder links between canvases
- Handle image references appropriately

## UI
- Export OPML button in toolbar (alongside existing JSON export)
- Import OPML option (alongside existing JSON import)
- Consider: export single canvas vs export entire tree

## Replaces
- Current naive markdown/ASCII indent format
- More rigorous than current JSON export for hierarchy

title: Add non-destructive image filters (grayscale, sepia, etc.)
description:
Implement non-destructive image filters that are stored in element data and applied via CSS filters.

## Filter Properties to Support
- grayscale: 0-100%
- brightness: 0-200% (100 = normal)
- contrast: 0-200% (100 = normal)
- blur: 0-20px
- sepia: 0-100%
- saturate: 0-200% (100 = normal)
- hue-rotate: 0-360deg
- invert: 0-100%
- opacity: 0-100%

## Requirements
- Store filter settings in elementData.filters object
- Apply filters via CSS filter property on image elements
- Filters persist through save/load cycle
- Reset filters option to clear all filters
- Non-destructive: original image is never modified

## Technical Implementation
- Extend image element data model with 'filters' property
- Add buildFilterString() utility to convert filter object to CSS
- Apply filters in addImageToCanvas() during render
- Update filters via updateElementPosition() or new updateElementFilters() function
- Integrate with undo/redo system
close_reason: Filter infrastructure complete. Context menu integration works for quick toggles. Ready for dependent issues (filter slider panel, quick toggles, presets).

title: Add comprehensive keyboard shortcuts with discoverability
description:

- Cmd/Ctrl+[: Send Backward

- Tooltips on toolbar buttons should show shortcuts

## Requirements
- Respect platform conventions (Cmd on Mac, Ctrl on Windows/Linux)
- Don't conflict with browser shortcuts
- Shortcuts work when canvas is focused

## Note
This issue tracks the overall keyboard shortcut strategy. Individual feature issues should implement their specific shortcuts.

- Folders: Rename, Open, Change Color, Delete

- Use existing modal/UI patterns from color-manager.js as reference
